summary: This document is a series of emails from whistleblower Christopher J. Dilorio to various judges and SEC officials, primarily dated May 21, 2021, with earlier threads from 2020. Dilorio alleges massive, ongoing securities fraud involving naked short selling, money laundering, and SEC obstruction. He specifically implicates Knight Capital/KCG/Virtu (NITE), UBS, Jefferies, and others in a scheme involving OTC market shells, and accuses the SEC of using his whistleblower information to both bring and obstruct complaints while denying him compensation.

persons.name: Christopher J. Dilorio
persons.context: The author of the emails, alleging massive securities fraud, SEC obstruction, and seeking whistleblower awards for information provided to the SEC and FINRA.

persons.name: Judge Swain
persons.context: Addressed in the initial email regarding the SEC's actions and the Knight Capital/Virtu transaction.

persons.name: Judge Cave
persons.context: Addressed in a 2020 email regarding evidence related to the Jefferies/Handler bailout of NITE and the Virtu/KCG merger.

persons.name: Judge Jones
persons.context: Addressed alongside Judge Cave in the 2020 email regarding evidence of fraud.

persons.name: Rich Handler
persons.context: Repeatedly accused of being part of a "criminal/corrupt relationship" with the SEC to bail out Knight Capital/NITE. Referred to derogatorily as "Little Dick Handler".

persons.name: Doug Cifu
persons.context: Accused of refusing to disclose KCG's Q2 2017 financials before the Virtu acquisition and writing down billions in "fraud assets" (naked short fails).

persons.name: Jay Clayton
persons.context: Accused of conflicts of interest due to his former firm Sullivan Cromwell's role in Knight/KCG/Virtu transactions and of criminal obstruction.

persons.name: Jared Fishman
persons.context: Named as an advisor to Knight/KCG/Virtu transactions, allegedly facilitating fraud alongside SEC Chair Clayton.

persons.name: Dan Coleman
persons.context: Former head of equities at UBS during its Reg SHO violations; became CEO of KCG after the Getco reverse merger. Implicated in the fraud.

persons.name: Jane Norberg
persons.role: SEC Office of the Whistleblower Chief
persons.context: Primary SEC recipient of Dilorio's lengthy appeal regarding the denial of his whistleblower award for the Oppenheimer action. Accused of being part of the obstruction.

persons.name: Sean McKessy
persons.context: Former head of the SEC Whistleblower Office who solicited information from Dilorio. His handling of the information is questioned.

persons.name: Robin Traxler
persons.context: FINRA official with whom Dilorio corresponded extensively in 2012 about trading in shells like Colorado Goldfields and AppTech.

persons.name: Carl Hoecker
persons.context: Accused by Dilorio of conducting inadequate investigations into his complaints, failing to interview him, and not informing Congress of serious allegations.

persons.name: Joshua Sason
persons.context: Named in Dilorio's TCRs and later the subject of a 2019 SEC complaint regarding microcap fraud through Hanover/Magna. Linked to NITE trading activity.

persons.name: Justin Keener
persons.context: Cited in Dilorio's 2013 TCR and later the subject of a 2020 SEC complaint. Allegedly involved in penny stock fraud with NITE as the executing broker.

persons.name: David Urban
persons.role: Trump Campaign Advisor, NITE Board Member
persons.context: Mentioned as sitting on the board of NITE and having his own alleged money-laundering shell (FSD Parma).

persons.name: Steven Peikin
persons.context: Accused of conflicts of interest due to his previous work at Sullivan Cromwell with Jared Fishman and should have recused himself from NITE/Virtu matters.

persons.name: Andrew Ceresney
persons.context: Former SEC official who represented UBS before joining the SEC. Cited for being "shocked" at low SAR filings by broker-dealers in 2015.

persons.name: Mary Jo White
persons.context: Former SEC Chair whose law firm Debevoise is mentioned in relation to NewLead. Accused of conflicts with Swiss bank clients.

persons.name: Oleg Firer
persons.context: CEO of Net Element (NETE), an alleged money-laundering shell with numerous AML red flags, kept running by SEC obstruction.

persons.name: Martin Schlaff
persons.context: Austrian/Israeli businessman controlling Alpha Capital Anstalt, linked to various shells like IMDS and money laundering.

persons.name: Mr. Kamensky
persons.context: An individual being prosecuted, whom Dilorio argues is being unfairly targeted while bigger players like Handler/Jefferies are protected by the SEC.

connections.description: Handler is the CEO of Jefferies, which Dilorio alleges repeatedly bailed out the "criminal entity" NITE (Knight Capital).
Both previously worked at the law firm Sullivan Cromwell, which advised Knight/KCG/Virtu on transactions Dilorio alleges were fraudulent.
Coleman ran Equities at UBS during its period of Reg SHO violations and cross-border AML issues before becoming CEO of KCG.
Alleged to have traded billions of shares in the same OTC market shells (e.g., CGFIA, APCX) to facilitate naked short selling and money laundering.
Sason operated through entities like Hanover and Magna, which were involved in converting bogus obligations into worthless certificates dumped via NITE.
Dilorio submitted multiple TCRs (Tip, Complaint, Referrals) and correspondence to the SEC OWB, alleging they used his information but denied him awards and obstructed investigations.
Urban sits on the board of directors of NITE (Knight Capital's market-making arm).
Ceresney represented UBS prior to joining the SEC, creating a conflict of interest per Dilorio's allegations.

events.title: Knight Capital "Trading Glitch"
events.description: A software glitch at Knight Capital caused massive erroneous trades, leading to a $460 million loss. Dilorio alleges this was not a glitch but proof of Knight's insolvency due to naked short fails, and that it triggered an SEC-orchestrated bailout.

events.title: Getco/Knight Reverse Merger Closes
events.description: The reverse merger between Knight Capital and Getco closed, forming KCG Holdings. Dilorio alleges this was a "bailout" of an insolvent, criminal enterprise facilitated by the SEC.

events.title: SEC Oppenheimer AML Action (Covered Action 2015-016)
events.description: The SEC brought an anti-money laundering enforcement action against Oppenheimer & Co. Dilorio claims this action was based on his whistleblower information but was narrowly crafted to protect NITE and UBS.

events.title: Virtu Acquisition of KCG Closes
events.description: Virtu Financial acquired KCG Holdings. Dilorio alleges massive fraud: Virtu CEO Cifu refused to disclose KCG's Q2 2017 financials and wrote down over $4 billion in naked short fails, inflating the tangible book value to benefit Handler/Jefferies.

events.title: SEC Charges Joshua Sason et al.
events.description: The SEC charged Joshua Sason and others for microcap fraud. Dilorio claims this was his information, filed years earlier in separate TCRs, and questions why executing brokers like NITE were not implicated.

events.title: SEC Preliminary Denial of Dilorio's Award Claim
events.description: The SEC Office of the Whistleblower issued a preliminary denial of Dilorio's award application for the 2015 Oppenheimer action, claiming investigators never saw his information. Dilorio appeals, calling this fabricated and part of the obstruction.

events.title: SEC Files Reg SHO Complaint Against BTIG
events.description: The SEC filed a Regulation SHO complaint against BTIG for mis-marking short sales as long. Dilorio contrasts this with no action against Virtu for similar alleged conduct in 2017.

keyFacts: The whistleblower, Christopher Dilorio, alleges Knight Capital/KCG/Virtu (operating as market maker 'NITE') is a criminal enterprise whose core business is abusive naked short selling of OTC market shells to facilitate money laundering.

Dilorio claims the SEC has criminally obstructed investigations into his allegations since 2011, choosing to bail out and protect Knight/NITE rather than shut down the fraud, creating a 'Do Not Investigate' list.

Key evidence cited includes Knight inadvertently sending 4,000 worthless securities to JPMorgan as collateral in 2012, and a 2013 CGFIA filing noting a 'Global Lock' due to actions by a third-party broker-dealer, which Dilorio says proves naked shorting.

The 2017 Virtu acquisition of KCG is alleged to be fraudulent, with Virtu CEO Doug Cifu refusing to publish KCG's Q2 2017 financials and writing down over $4 billion in 'fraud assets' (naked short fails) to inflate the tangible book value.

Dilorio accuses the SEC Whistleblower Office of using his information to both bring and obstruct complaints while denying him rightful compensation, with the 2021 denial for the 2015 Oppenheimer action being a 'fabricated' excuse.
